title: What to do next, I receive a summon letter from Portfolio Recovery Associates fro Credit Debt.
question: Hi received a summon letter yesterday by Portfolio Recovery Associates, the date was on Oct 15 2012, this is the first time I see it 12/07/2012. It says i need to respond within 30 days but they have been sending to my old address. how do I file a a response? Not sure what I need to do to avoid the default. Should I contact them and try to settle? What are my options.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Debt settlement,Bankruptcy and debt,Filing a lawsuit
answers:
Yes, you do need to file an Answer to the Complaint. Even if you want to settle this debt, filing an answer and showing that you are prepared to litigate the case will ensure that you will have bargaining power. In most debt-buyer cases, the complaints are not verified, so you can file a General Denial (PLD-050) which is not difficult. You must also get a family member or friend to mail a copy of the Answer to the plaintiff's attorney and fill out a Proof of Service by Mail (POS-030). The General Denial and the Proof of Service by Mail need to be filed with the court, and you will need to pay a first appearance fee ($225 if the complaint seeks less than $10,000).

Once you have filed your answer, you should consult with a debt collection defense attorney about how to proceed.

Good luck!
I suggest you consult with a collections defense attorney who practices in the county in which you were sued. Sometimes debt buyer plaintiff cases are defensible. Good luck.

This is probably an old debt. You probably have defenses to the lawsuit. Just as important, because Portfolio Recovery is a "debt buyer", it is not likely that it has all of the documents and witnesses that are necessary to prove their case if you go to court.

You will be best served if you contact an attorney who is experienced in defending debt collection cases. The attorney can give you more specific advise and can negotiate on your behalf far better than you can yourself. You have time. The 30 day period runs from the date of service of the Summons upon you, not the date when the case was filed.

Richard Scott Lysle

The date the lawsuit was filed (presumably the 10/15 date) is irrelevant. The 30-day clock starts ticking when you were served with the summons. If you believe they may have served you at a previous address, you can contact the court to get a copy of the proof of service, which will show the date on which the plaintiff served you. If you find out that the 30 days have passed, you can typically have the time to respond extended by contacting the plaintiff's attorneys to make the request.

What you should do at this point is a little difficult to tell without knowing more about your situation. As a bankruptcy attorney, receiving a summons is often what drives clients into my office because the debt they've been sued for us just one of many, many debts. If that's the case for you, bankruptcy might be the best option.

If you have the ability to pay this debt either in a lump sum settlement or over time with payments, then settling now before the plaintiff incurs more costs in the lawsuit might be a good option. Debt settlement or litigation attorneys, among others, can help you with this.

If you believe this debt is invalid for some reason or that Portfolio Recovery acted illegally in their collection of the debt, you should consult with a debt collection or consumer rights attorney to see if you have a case against the collector.

Even if this is your only debt, and it's fairly small, you would be wise to at least consult with one or more of the attorneys I've mentioned above. Most will offer a free consultation, so there is no risk.

Best of luck!

When was the date you were served? You typically have 30 days from the date you were served to file an answer. After the 30th day, the Plaintiff can ask the court to enter a default judgement, whereby you could be liable for the full face of complaint? You may have defenses, and this is certainly not a case you want to litigate alone.
